note.p: Français 24864, Bibliothéque national de France, Paris. Paris, 23 August, 1410.
Light colored paper with some humidity and ink marks on folio 14 and numerous humidity marks especially in folios 176-178bis.

Folios 14-18 are part of the same quire (from 14-21, but only the first four folios and a half contain the Lamentation). The victorine foliation dates from the 15th century and it was written in thick Arabic numerals on the top right.

Folios 176-178bis. ff. 4. Like almost all the manuscripts of Saint-Victor, the foliation dates from the 15th/16th century and it was written in thick Arabic numerals on the top right. Folio 178bis was later on numbered.
There is no evidence of ruling nor pricking. There is one column with 24-29 lines.

The text for "Lamentation" is written in dark brown ink. The text seems to have been written by one scribe in a cursive calligraphic script. The name of the Duc de Berry is written in thick letters and underlined on folios 16 and 18 ("O duc de Berry"). Punctuation marks are also used, especially the period. There are no corrections.

The text for "Moralized Proverbs" is written in faded brown ink with a faded red for the explicit. The text seems to have been written by one scribe in a high cursive script. This script is very similar to that used in the transcription of the Dit de la pasture at the end of the manuscript in Chantilly, Bibl. du Château, Ms. 492. Punctuation marks are also used, especially scansion bar, except when the break falls in the middle of a word. There are some corrections done by the hand of the main scribe.
There is no ornamental decoration, nor decorated initials, nor any miniatures.
The manuscript is bound with full scraped sheepskin rebuilt in the 20th century in the medieval style.

The "Lamentation" manuscript can be dated to the 23 of August, 1410, according to the colophon, a date that confirms the watermark on the paper. This is the only copy known to have survived of the Lamentation, this autograph on paper without any decoration has all the characteristics of a first time exemplar.

Provenance: Abbey of Saint-Victor where Claude de Grandrue gave the manuscript the shelfmark TT7 in 1514 underneath the table of contents along with other shelfmarks on folio 1 (C.d.33, 509, 879, 623). The diverse elements of this collection were gathered by Guillaume Tuysselet in the mid-15th century. The manuscripts from Saint-Victor entered the Bibliothèque de la Nation (the future BnF) after the French Revolution. There is a stamp from the Second Empire (1852-1870) on folios 176 and 178bis.
The "Moralized Proverbs" manuscript can be dated to the 27 of October, 1405. This is the only copy of this book to be dated.

The manuscript contains several texts: Treaties of edification in prose and verse, by Christine de Pisan, Saint Bernard; le Pastoral fo Saint Gregory, etc.
*The information given here comes from direct observation and from Ouy, Gilbert, Christine Reno and Inès Villela-Petit. Album Christine de Pizan . Turnhout: Brepols, 2012.
